The chlorine is used for disinfection of wastewater effluent prior to discharge.  The sulfur dioxide is added at the end of the chlorination disinfection process to remove residual chlorine.  The system operates in the following manner: Pressurized chlorine (sulfur dioxide) gas within a ton container is reduced to vacuum by tank-mounted vacuum regulator valves. It is metered through rotameters, and rate valves automatically set the amount in proportion to flow and desired chlorine residual. Finally, chlorine and sulfur dioxide are drawn into water solutions by the passage of pressurized water through injectors.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



It is the policy of the City of Mt. Shasta that the receipt, storage, and handling of RS's at its facility be done in a manner that meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of accidental releases to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  To accomplish this goal, the City has gathered safety information on chlorine (sulfur dioxide) and on the process, equipment, and procedures involving chlorine (sulfur dioxide); and performed a structured assessment of hazards of the process and external events which might affect the process. The City has performed an offsite consequences analysis of defined release scenarios; established a written program to prevent and mitigate accidental releases. It has also established a written emergency action program and coordinated with emergency response agencies. The City is a non-responding facility per California General Industrial Safety Order 3220.



ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS



Administrative controls in effect at the City of Mt. Shasta are used to mitigate the severity of the Worst and Alternative Case release scenarios. They include the C

ity's written policies and procedures for training operators, written procedures for control of the inventory of chemicals at the facility, and policies regarding quality level of replacement materials and components for the chlorine system.



MITIGATION MEASURES



Passive mitigation was considered to limit the severity of the Worst Case scenario.  No passive mitigation was considered to limit the severity of the Alternative Case scenario.  Active mitigation was considered for the Alternative Case, in the form of the response of properly trained and equipped personnel from the Shasta Cascade HazMat Response Team (SCHMRT) following established emergency response procedures. This team is the response organization for a multi-county area and is based in Redding, CA, with responders in several counties.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS



General accidental release prevention programs instituted by the City of Mt. Shasta are categorized as administrative (management) programs, procedures, training, engineering controls, and emergency response programs.



The City of Mt. Shasta has instituted a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program meeting OSHA requirements at 29 CFR 1910.119 and CalOSHA GISO Section 5189 covering the disinfection and dechlorination processes at the Wastewater Treatment Plant.  The PSM Program constitutes the general accidental release prevention program for the City's operations at this facility. The program and document management procedures, included in the PSM Program, are used as the Risk Management Program management system.



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS



Release prevention steps specific to chlorine (sulfur dioxide) have been identified and implemented.  These include:

?    improvements in operating procedures, 

?    installing windsocks, 

?    replacing the manual hoist with a motorized trolley, 

?    sealing off the doorways connecting the chlorine storage and rotameter rooms from the rest of the Operations Buildi

ng, and 

?    improving the egress of the ton container storage room by adding a personnel door with panic hardware. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no reportable accidents involving chlorine at this facility within the past five years. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The City of Mt. Shasta's Emergency Action plan applicable to chlorine and sulfur dioxide has been coordinated with Siskiyou County Hazardous Materials Management Group, the agency responsible for hazardous materials inventory reporting and release response coordination. The emergency response program is coordinated with the seven-county Shasta-Cascade HazMat Response Team (SCHMRT).  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analysis, which the City of Mt. Shasta committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.  This also includes any recommendations arising from reviewing Chlorine Institute RAGAGEP information. The facility plans construct a new plant at the current site within the next 3-5 years.  It will move from chlorine to ultraviolet disinfection at that time.  This program will be deregistered when that occurs.
